docs.lead_paragraph: IT is impossible to separate the terrorist attacks last month from the subsequent gyrations in the financial markets. But without seeking to minimize the impact of the attacks, it may be worth recalling that the global economy was in trouble before Sept. 11. And even if the United States and its allies prevail in the war against terrorism, the world must still cope with deep-rooted problems created by the enormous amounts of capital that can move instantaneously across borders. Since Sept. 11, of course, the debate swirling around globalization -- until then the hot-button issue at every international gathering -- has been muted, overwhelmed by the onslaught on the icons of American financial and military power: the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The suicidal passions that drove those attacks will take months, if not years, to absorb and understand.

headline.main: Can the I.M.F. Tame the Capital Beast?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush and Congress are working on legislation to provide health benefits to hundreds of thousands of people laid off in recent months. But they disagree over how to deliver the aid and how much to spend. Nearly two-thirds of Americans receive health insurance through employers. When workers lose their jobs, they often lose health insurance as well. Congress is considering several approaches. One would help laid-off workers pay premiums so they could keep coverage under group health plans operated by their former employers.

headline.main: Bills Would Help New Jobless Keep Insurance

docs.abstract: Pres Bush and Congress on working on bills to provide health benefits to hundreds of thousands of people laid off in recent months; Congress weighs several approaches, including bills to help laid-off workers pay premiums to keep coverage under employer-run group health plans and provide coverage for others under Medicaid; Pres Bush favors giving states grants that could be used to pay health insurance premiums; his proposal to let states take money from Children's Health Insurance Program to fund insurance for unemployed has spurred storm of criticism in Congress (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICAN companies had Western Europe frightened. They were overrunning the Continent, displacing native enterprise. Anger swelled at American imperialism. But a French journalist, J. J. Servan-Schreiber, had a different explanation. In passionate prose, full of respect for the United States, he argued in ''The American Challenge,'' a best seller in 1968, that America's success reflected a bold, innovative corporate sector combined with generous government spending. The two reinforced each other, generating expansion and prosperity. ''This takes us a long way from the old image of the United States -- a country where business was not only separate from government but constantly struggling with it,'' Mr. Servan-Schreiber wrote.

headline.main: Government Spending Is Back. But for What?

docs.abstract: Louis Uchitelle column says it is good that federal spending is once against being used to revive economy, but bad that focus in on short term rather than long-term spending on infrastructure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the last two years John Wilhelm, president of the nation's largest hotel workers' union, has been considered the man to watch in the labor movement. He is the favorite, many union leaders say, to succeed John J. Sweeney as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Succeeding at a tough task that Mr. Sweeney assigned him, Mr. Wilhelm engineered a surprising about-face by the nation's labor unions, getting them to drop a longstanding hostility toward immigrant labor and embrace the cause of low-wage immigrant workers. And Mr. Wilhelm, a graduate of Yale, has developed a reputation as labor's leading strategist in an area that many union leaders deem vitally important: persuading nonunion workers to join unions.

headline.main: A Labor Leader on the Rise as His Workers Are Down

docs.abstract: Public Lives interview with John Wilhelm, president of nation's largest hotel workers' union, on 'catastrophic' situation in industry since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; Wilhelm, who is favored to succeed John J Sweeney as AFL-CIO, has reputation for persuading nonunion workers to join unions, but is now trying to help members laid off around country because of sharp drop in travel (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the urgent search for people exposed to anthrax moved today into the post offices of South Florida, the workers who sort the nation's mail became increasingly concerned that they might have distributed the deadly disease and come in contact with it. ''We're all in a state of fear,'' said Connie, a distribution clerk at the main post office in Miami, who would not let her last name be used. ''After 30 years, I want to retire -- I don't want to go out with anthrax.''

headline.main: For Mail Clerks in Florida, A New and Dire Concern
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE POSTAL WORKERS

docs.abstract: As urgent search for people exposed to anthrax moves into post offices of South Florida, workers who sort nation's mail are becoming increasingly concerned that they might have distributed deadly disease and came in contact with it; federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says it has tested about 20 Boca Raton postal workers who might have come into contact with mail bound for stricken Florida publishing company, American Media Inc; one mail distribution center is briefly shut down and evacuated after authorities learn that one of employees picks up American Media's mail each morning; Judy Johnson, president of unio's Miami local, says government should test all 140 mail clerks in Boca Raton area and install machines that can detect hazardous materials in packages (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House and Congress are engaged in a debate over the best way for the government to respond to the economic downturn now clearly under way. To help clarify the issues, Business Day asked the four experts who write the weekly Economic Scene -- Alan B. Krueger, Jeff Madrick, Virginia Postrel and Hal Varian -- to present brief viewpoints. Here are their comments. TEMPORARY STIMULUS NEEDED -- A stimulus package is desirable because economic growth had ground to a halt even before the attacks of Sept. 11 and our military response raised the possibility that consumers and investors will panic, causing a sharp and sudden contraction in economic activity.

headline.main: Some Views on How to Steer the Economy Toward Recovery

docs.lead_paragraph: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the insurance companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center, has found a new home in Midtown, becoming yet another company forced to move its big chunk of offices away from the financial district. The company signed a deal yesterday to move into three floors in a 32-story tower at 11 West 42nd Street, near Fifth Avenue. But it is taking less than a quarter of the space the company had at the trade center, where it was one of the largest tenants in the complex, with about 460,000 square feet.

headline.main: Empire Blue Cross Takes Space in Midtown

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JOSEPH KELLER His Motto: 'Let's Do It!' On that last Sunday, Joseph Keller, bona fide grown-up -- father, husband, homeowner in Park Ridge, N.J., and department head at the Marriott World Trade Center Hotel -- had what would be a final fling with his daredevil teenage self. He and two buddies from high school got together and dusted off their old bicycle freestyling stunts. Mr. Keller, 31, who had competed in the extreme sport, still had the chops to pull off a funky chicken. (Don't ask.) ''If you were looking for someone to egg you on,'' said his friend Prentice Chang, ''Joe was like: 'Let's do it!' A lot of people followed his direction.''

headline.main: A Bicycle Daredevil, a Fearless Cook and a 79-Year-Old Mountaineer
